item.title: 10 Battlefield Games With The Best Storylines
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • The Battlefield series is renowned for its intense multiplayer battles and destructible environments, but it also offers compelling single-player campaigns that explore different aspects of warfare.
  • These Battlefield games transport players to different historical and fictional war settings, offering immersive experiences and compelling narratives.
  • While some games in the series received mixed reviews, the quality of storytelling in the Battlefield series has remained consistent, with attention to detail, authentic experiences, and emotional themes that captivate players.

The Battlefield series is known for its intense multiplayer battles, large-scale maps, and destructible environments. The series always had a strong emphasis on gameplay. However, over the years, it has also become renowned for its single-player campaigns, which have often offered compelling stories that explore different aspects of warfare throughout history.

From the gritty realism of Battlefield 1 's depiction of World War I to the humor and camaraderie of the Bad Company subseries, the Battlefield games tell a wide range of stories that still keep players invested in the game's worlds. While the series has had its ups and downs in terms of critical reception and commercial success, one thing that has remained consistent is the quality of its storytelling.

Updated September 24, 2024, by Gerardo Molina: Over the years, the Battlefield franchise has been under the observation of many critics and players. Often compared to other similar games like Call of Duty, Battlefield knows how to set itself apart by straying from the classic commercial FPS formula and striving for a much higher degree of realism. With titles like Battlefield 1, which very accurately represents the horror of World War 1 and the stressful situation that soldiers lived in the trenches, the Battlefield franchise shows players the raw side of war.

While some of the franchise's titles have experienced a few negative reviews in a fair share of multiplayer instances, the story mode in almost every game is always rich and full of drama and action.

10 Battlefield 2142 (2006)

Warfare Set In The Middle Of An Ice Age

  • Platform(s): PC, Mac
  • Released: October 17, 2006
  • Developer(s): DICE
  • Genre: First-person shooter

As the game's name suggests, Battlefield 2142 is set in the 22nd century, right in the middle of an ice age. Players can choose to play as either one of the factions; the Pan-Asian Coalition (PAC), or the European Union (EU). As both superpowers fight over control of the last few remaining resources on a dying version of Earth, players will have to hone their survival skills and perfect their aim to win.

While Battlefield 2142 does not have a story mode per se, the political setting around it makes for a very interesting experience that focuses on large-scale multiplayer combat.

9 Battlefield 1943 (2009)

A True Depiction Of World War II Battles Offered In A Simpler, More Concentrated Way

Battlefield 1943 's plot is straightforward, focusing on the conflicts that arose in the Pacific Theater between the United States Marine Corps and the Imperial Japanese Navy. Multiplayer fights take place on battlefields based on famous Pacific Theater sites, in which players can choose to play as the United States Marine Corps or the Japanese Imperial Navy. It also allows players to experience renowned battles from the Pacific theater of World War II through a combination of teamwork, vehicle combat, and strategic gaming.

Battlefield 1943 does not have a rich or comprehensive backstory in conventional terms, which is why it was ranked the lowest. It's not extremely narrative-heavy, but it does set the stage aesthetically for the conflicts. Battlefield 1943 's multiplayer features and violent, realistic combat experiences are what draw most gamers in, not the game's narrative depth.

8 Battlefield 5 (2018)

Brings Players Into An Immersive World War II Experience

Taking place during World War II, Battlefield 5 is a first-person shooter. Several individuals representing different countries and perspectives on the war are featured in the single-player campaign. The campaign's chapters, which cover various aspects of the battle, give players a wide range of perspectives and opportunities to feel real emotion. In this role-playing game, players take on the personas of several characters fighting for recognition and equality during World War II, such as Norwegian resistance fighter Solveig, British criminal Billy Bridger, German tank commander Peter Müller, and Deme Cisse and his fellow troops.

Most fans found this game incomplete and quite boring, but they agreed that its graphics and mechanics were a nice surprise. The campaign explores themes such as sacrifice, loss, and the human cost of war. Even though Battlefield 5 doesn't offer impressive content, fans still enjoy the game and have fun going through the stories.

7 Battlefield Hardline (2015)

A Great Crime Story That Deviates From The Franchise's Classic Warfare Setting

Set in modern-day Miami, Battlefield Hardline focuses on the story of detective Nick Mendoza, who dives deep into the corrupt underworld of the Miami drug and mafia scene. With a strong focus on its single-player story, this title has enough to entertain both fans of the franchise and newcomers alike with its intrigue.

Battlefield Hardline features car chases, smaller urban combat environments, and heists that complement each other well and deliver an overall pleasant experience that players will want to repeat more than once. While it would seem that making such a drastic change to the franchise would result in mixed or negative reviews, this luckily wasn't the case. While the game isn't the best-rated in the franchise's history, it was mostly well-received.

6 Battlefield 2 (2005)

Features Dynamic Multiplayer Combat Between The United States, China, And The Middle Eastern Coalition

Battlefield 2 takes place in the future and centers on fictitious battles between the United States, China, and a fabricated Middle Eastern coalition. Players can pick a side and fight in multiplayer modes like Conquest, where teams battle to seize and retain control points across vast areas. They can also take on the roles of members of several military factions and engage in online conflicts set in real-world crisis zones.

When compared to other games in the Battlefield series , Battlefield 2: Modern Combat is widely acclaimed for its compelling storyline due to its more sophisticated and character-driven narrative. The story that unfolds in this title is one full of deceit that eventually culminates in a satisfying revelation that points players in the direction of the true enemy. The game's graphics, audio, and cutscenes were of outstanding quality, further adding to the immersion, storytelling, and realistic settings present in the game.

5 Battlefield 4 (2013)

Focuses On A Fictional Conflict Between The United States, China, And Russia In A Distant Future Setting

The single-player campaign of Battlefield 4 tells the story of Sergeant Daniel Recker, also known as "Tombstone," a member of a U.S. Special Forces squad. It takes place in several locations around the world as the squad attempts to stop the plans of a rogue Chinese general named Chang Wei, who is threatening world peace.

Along the way, Recker's crew must fight enemy soldiers, survive natural disasters, and overcome technological malfunctions. The campaign explores themes such as loyalty, betrayal, and the moral complexity of war. Fans' opinions are mixed, as some believe that the story is good but pretty standard, while others are disappointed in the lack of emotions the game evokes.

4 Battlefield 1 (2016)

Its Captivating Storyline Transports Players To The Mud And Dust Of World War 1

Battlefield 1 is set in World War I and features a single-player campaign that tells the story of different characters and their experiences in the war. Players take on the roles of Frederick Bishop, an Australian messenger; Zara Ghufran, a Bedouin rebel; Luca Vincenzo Cocchiola, an Italian Arditi soldier; Clyde Blackburn, a pilot in the Royal Flying Corps; and Daniel Edwards, a British tank driver during World War I.

One of the unique features of the campaign is the way it uses different gameplay mechanics for each character, such as piloting a biplane or sneaking through enemy lines as a Bedouin warrior. Overall, Battlefield 1 offers a powerful and emotionally charged experience for fans of the first-person shooter genre and history buffs alike. Throughout the player's exploration, it offers themes like sacrifice, loss, and the human toll of combat.

3 Battlefield: Bad Company (2008)

Follows A Misfit Squad's Quest For Personal Interests Amidst A Backdrop Of Military Conflict

Battlefield Bad Company's campaign begins with Preston Marlowe, a United States soldier sent to be the newest member of the B Company, known as the Bad Company for its troublemakers. After completing a few dangerous missions, the members begin to realize that there's more than just the war they should be worried about, as they uncover a well-hidden truth.

The game's story is popular for its humor, dynamic environments, and destructible scenery that add a unique element to the gameplay. As players grow immersed in the squad's unity and the developing character dynamics, they are transported to other locations throughout the game. This general concept features the game's central focus on the antics of the charmingly odd troops of Bad Company as they make their way through the mayhem of battle with wit and solidarity.

2 Battlefield 3 (2011)

A Captivating Narrative That Transports Players To War Zones Around The World

Following the story of Sergeant Henry Blackburn, a Marine in the United States military, Battlefield 3 takes place in several locations, including Iraq, Iran, and New York City. Blackburn and his team battle various terrorists across the globe, trying to prevent the war from advancing to its nuclear phase. The campaign is known for its cinematic and intense moments, as well as its emphasis on teamwork and strategy.

The game features a mix of vehicle and infantry combat, with players using a variety of weapons to complete objectives. While the game received praise for its cinematic and action-packed cutscenes, it was also criticized for its linear story and for the fact that players' choices don't affect the narrative, making them feel like nothing they do matters anyway.

1 Battlefield: Bad Company 2 (2010)

This Worldwide Adventure Revolves Around A Hidden Weapon And A Global Plot

Battlefield: Bad Company 2 follows the same group of soldiers from Bad Company as they are sent on a new mission to prevent a dangerous weapon from falling into the wrong hands. The game's story centers on a squad of characters, each with a distinct personality and a good dose of humor, and how the player character Preston Marlowe and squad leader Sergeant Samuel Redford create a strong emotional connection during their mission. The story takes place in various locations around the world, including South America and Russia.

The game's campaign is known for its more serious tone compared to its predecessor and its emphasis on character development, with the soldiers of the Bad Company facing moral dilemmas and grappling with their own motivations. The game features improved dynamic environments, allowing players to use their surroundings to their advantage during combat. Overall, Battlefield: Bad Company 2 's campaign offers a thrilling and immersive experience for players looking for a gripping storyline and intense gameplay.

item.title: The Hardest Online Multiplayer Games, Ranked
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Some of the hardest multiplayer games, like Call of Duty: Warzone, offer complex environments and challenges.
  • Overcooked 2 emphasizes teamwork with new levels, obstacles, and advanced difficulty.
  • Club Penguin, though shut down in 2017, required dedication and purchases for a challenging MMO experience.

Playing with friends or even strangers should be a fun thing to do. What's the point of video games if players don't have fun? For some, the adrenaline rush of a challenging game is the best part of any video game despite the many offers to buy upgrades, level boosts, or loot boxes to make things easier.

Whether it is for its fast-paced environments like Call of Duty: Warzone, horrendous scripting issues like Madden Ultimate Team mode, or perplexing tactics like those used in Dota 2 , mastering these games can be frustrating. These are some of the hardest multiplayer games when it's time to break some controllers.

Updated September 25, 2024 by Kristy Ambrose: First-person shooters, adventure games, and RPGs are just some examples of the many forms that multiplayer games can take. Sharing a virtual space even when it comes to old-school online or local multiplayer activities opens up some interesting possibilities for video games, especially with recent trends in virtual reality and greater availability of satellite internet.

The difficulty level of a game is always a matter of opinion, with the controversy raging about "story mode" and other opportunities to turn down the difficulty level of certain games, but these are some of the hardest multiplayer games to learn and master.

21 Club Penguin

Requires Organization And Dedication

  • Developer: New Horizon Interactive, RocketSnail Games, Disney Interactive Studios
  • Platforms: Online
  • Type of Multiplayer: Massively Multiplayer Online (MMO)
  • Launch Date: October 24, 2005

It might sound laughable to include Disney's Club Penguin , but it was a hard massive-multiplayer game to master for a beginner. Although it's designed for children, Club Penguin required a certain amount of dedication to purchase more giant igloos, which served as players' penguin bases.

Unfortunately, as of this writing, Club Penguin was already shut down in 2017. Many fans duplicate the game onto another website, but most of them have been taken down by the DMCA. However, there's an updated version called New Club Penguin , a fan-made game that still appears to be standing.

20 Overcooked 2

Focused On Teamwork And Kitchen Design

  • Developer: Team17, Ghost Town Games
  • Platforms: Linux, macOS, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4 and 5, Windows, Xbox One and Series X/S, Google Stadia
  • Type of Multiplayer: Simulation
  • Launch Date: August 7, 2018

The original Overcooked had both single-player and multiplayer modes, and its popularity inspired a sequel that takes the teamwork factor and design to the next level. The second game also added some impressive new settings and clever transitions between levels but still tends to overwhelm inexperienced players.

Overcooked 2 is one of the hardest multiplayer games at more advanced levels, with more obstacles and challenges that the players have to work together to surmount. Gamers can join their friends to make a group or use an online matching service to find teams.

19 Apex Legends

Battle Royale With Intense Teamwork and Planning

  • Developer: Respawn Entertainment
  • Platforms: PlayStation 4, Windows, Xbox One and Series X/S, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 5, Android, iOS
  • Type of Multiplayer: Battle Royale, First-person Hero Shooter
  • Launch Date: February 4, 2019

Any FPS game is going to require some teamwork and planning, which add a layer of difficulty to a game that's also multiplayer, online, and role-playing. When the game was first released, it focused on groups of three players, but since then single and two-player modes have also been added.

The main draw is the battle-royale environment and the inclusion of elements from fantasy, science fiction, and a variety of other genres. That's part of the appeal of Apex Legends for groups that want to game, interact, and create unique characters. Other advantages include free-to-play status, although there are a variety of microtransactions from which to choose, and cross-platform play capabilities.

18 TemTem

A High Learning Curve In A Complex Setting

  • Developer: Crema
  • Platforms: Microsoft Windows, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X/S
  • Type of Multiplayer: MMORPG
  • Launch Date: September 6, 2022

It looks like Pokemon and was inspired by the game, but TemTem was designed and developed by a Spanish company named Crema for the PlayStation 5. What sets Temtem apart is the higher learning curve, making this game more for adults and those with some previous experience with the fighting pet genre.

The game is classified as an MMORPG, with players exploring an area, raising and training magical animals, and using them to battle against both NPS and their fellow players. Like any proper MMO, the setting is creative and complex, made up of a series of diverse islands known as the Airborne Archipelago.

17 Madden NFL 23

Regular And Competitive Versions

  • Developer: EA Tiburon
  • Platforms: PlayStation 4 and 5, Windows, Xbox One and Series X/S
  • Type of Multiplayer: Sports Multiplayer
  • Launch Date: August 19, 2022

Like many of the games in this franchise, Madden NFL 23 has both a single and multiplayer mode, but this installment is noted for several basic quality-of-life improvements, like better trading and free-agency abilities. There were other cosmetic changes related to details in stadiums and better animation for action scenes on the field.

All of this made the game easier to play but more difficult to master. The new Field Pass system was implemented with this installment that included a Competitive version for those more dedicated gamers who want to spend extra time in multiplayer mode.

16 Call Of Duty: Warzone

Complex Controls That Originated With A Console-Friendly Design

  • Developer: Raven Software, Infinity Ward
  • Platforms: PlayStation 4, Windows, Xbox One
  • Type of Multiplayer: Battle Royale, FPS
  • Launch Date: March 10, 2020

Especially at the later stage of a difficult multiplayer game, playing Call of Duty: Warzone can be a burden for beginners. This complex game has already seen its fifth season and continues to impress players with its sophisticated controls and customization options.

Many top players have spent a considerable amount of real-life money to polish their in-game characters, so new characters have a hard time competing. On top of that, aiming and shooting using a DualShock 4 controller is harder than aiming with a gaming mouse. The only alternative to it is to connect a mouse to the console.

15 League Of Legends

An RTS Game With An Isometric Layout

  • Developer: Riot Games
  • Platforms: Microsoft Windows, macOS
  • Type of Multiplayer: Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA)
  • Launch Date: October 27, 2009

League of Legends is a multiplayer online game, but not an MMO in the sense that the focus is on the gameplay as opposed to an explorable open world. This game can be difficult or easy depending on the player's experience with real-time strategy games or an isometric layout.

The game will look familiar to those who played Warcraft 3 back in the day, and that's not a coincidence. The layout was inspired by a custom map from the classic game, Defense of the Ancients, and players choose and build hero characters that are based on famous characters from Warcraft lore.

14 Elder Scrolls Online

An RPG System With Virtually Limitless Build Options

  • Developer: ZeniMax Online Studios
  • Platforms: Windows, macOS, PlayStation 4 and 5, Xbox One and Series X/S
  • Type of Multiplayer: MMORPG
  • Launch Date: April 4, 2014

An online game based on the vast Elder Scrolls universe, ESO uses an RPG and leveling system based on TTGs like Harnmaster as opposed to Dungeons & Dragons. That means that anyone can use magic, use any weapon, or wear any armor. It doesn't have to be a complicated multiplayer game but it has that potential, and that's why most players are here.

The variety of builds available can accommodate any group, no matter how diverse when it comes to experience level or personal preference. Create characters and even a guild, form a party, and start a life of adventure in Tamriel.

13 Slither.io

Simple But Complex And Very Competitive

  • Developer: Steve Howse
  • Platforms: Browser, iOS, Android
  • Type of Multiplayer: Casual Multiplayer
  • Launch Date: March 25, 2016

Slither.io is a browser and smartphone-based game. It's pretty simple to play because it's highly similar to the classic 'Snake' arcade games, but don't underestimate how much Slither fans take this game seriously. It takes a severe amount of time to eat all the pellets and get the best score possible if players are lucky enough not to encounter any snake twice their size.

Upon its release, Slither.io has seen a massive amount of popularity, mostly coming from let's-play YouTubers like PewDiePie. It's easy to learn, difficult to master, and very habit-forming.

12 PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds

A Savage Battle Royale With Little Or No Safe Space

  • Developer: PUBG Studios
  • Platforms: Windows, Android, iOS, Xbox One and Series X/S, Stadia, PlayStation 4 and 5
  • Type of Multiplayer: Battle Royale
  • Launch Date: December 20, 2017

Playing the game formerly known as PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds (PUBG) is fun on mobile, but its PlayStation 4 version is something else. PUBG is a nightmare for a newbie jumping off a plane with a bunch of strangers. Chance is that players either land in a well-known territory and meet twice or three times more skilled players or get overrun by the decreasing safe zone.

On top of that, microtransactions have somewhat ruined the game among the fans. In the case of FIFA and Madden NFL Ultimate Team mode, it's almost impossible to get jobs done on the game without either dedicating a big amount of time or spending a big bank of money.

11 New World

A Survivalist MMO With Brutal PvP Combat

  • Developer: Amazon Games Orange Count
  • Platforms: Microsoft Windows
  • Type of Multiplayer: MMORPG
  • Launch Date: September 28, 2021

This MMO throws players in at the deep end with little in the way of introductions or tutorials, and that's a deliberate part of New World 's design. The survivalist nature of the game is part of the high learning curve in which players have to learn how to fight and survive or die in the wilderness. There are no classes in the game either, and it can be complicated building one from scratch, especially for those new to the genre.

Related
What Are Your Thoughts On New World: Aeternum's Open Beta?

I didn't get to experience much of New World's attempt at rebuilding its world, but what I saw was honestly quite impressive. The opening sequence feels like AGS finally figured out what to doo with New World's story, and they've revamped the intro to be more immersive and interesting. It's definitely revived my interest in the game, but I'm not sure if other veteran players share the same sentiment.

The setting is the island continent of Aeternum, and like other MMORPGs, it has a variety of locations that players can explore alone or with a party. Group activities include PvP objectives, Expeditions, and world bosses.

10 Sea Of Thieves

Marine Combat, Tactical Planning, And A Steep Learning Curve

  • Developer: Rare
  • Platforms: Windows, Xbox One and Series X/S
  • Type of Multiplayer: Action-adventure
  • Launch Date: March 20, 2018

For those that want a change from tactical shooters, medieval fantasy, or sports games, there's the high seas adventure game, Sea of Thieves . Not a lot of games feature ship combat and the ones that do lack the same details and features. This one, though, delivers on that front. There's also the option of sharing with one other player or joining up with a whole group of salty sailors.

The game is similar to other MMOs with a reputation for a steep learning curve, such as EVE Online. There's still a lot for players to do if they would prefer to emphasize ship and character customization as opposed to combat. However, most of the updates and improvements focus on the combat part of the game, which has been altered to be an on-demand feature.

9 Quake Champions

A Complicated FPS For Adults

  • Developer: id Software, Saber Interactive St. Petersburg
  • Platforms: Windows
  • Type of Multiplayer: First-person shooter
  • Launch Date: August 18, 2022

Quake: Champions was first announced at the Electronic Entertainment Expo of 2016, and players responded positively when the first version of the game was released a year later but had to wait until 2022 for the full version's release.

Quake was the type of game that was always designed with adults in mind, and the FPS version of the game reflects the same level of difficulty. It's a fast, complex game that includes a large number of playable characters and optional abilities for several different build possibilities, which might be overwhelming for new or inexperienced players.

8 Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege

A Lot To Learn And Precision Teamwork

  • Developer: Ubisoft Montreal
  • Platforms: PlayStation 4 and 5, Windows, Xbox One and Series X/S, Google Stadia
  • Type of Multiplayer: Tactical Shooter
  • Launch Date: December 1, 2015

It takes a lot to master Rainbow Six Siege online mode because players are required to learn a plethora of things at once. It's a teamwork game, hence many players who aren't the best at cooperating find this game hard. The multiplayer lobbies are also unpredictable but it's highly rewarding once players master them.

Teams are typically made of four players but extra DLC allows for varying numbers. It's also worth mentioning that players can even die at the hands of their allies, a twist that makes this multiplayer title even more difficult.

7 Counter-Strike

The Original Tactical FPS

  • Developer: Valve
  • Platforms: Windows, Xbox, OS X, Linux
  • Type of Multiplayer: Tactical FPS
  • Launch Date: November 9, 2000

Writing this list would never be complete without mentioning the legendary FPS game of them all, the original title in the Counter-Strike series. Several players even put more than hundreds of hours into mastering its maps and the wide variety of weapons before jumping into the real challenge against others.

Later titles are even more difficult because most CS: GO players are veterans of the game, making it harder for newbies to catch up. That makes the learning curve even steeper in what's already a difficult multiplayer game.

6 Keep Talking And Nobody Explodes

A Virtual Escape Room Consisting Of Puzzles And Teamwork

  • Developer: Steel Crate Games
  • Platforms: Android, Microsoft Windows, OS X, PlayStation 4, Linux, Nintendo Switch, Xbox One
  • Type of Multiplayer: Puzzle Multiplayer
  • Launch Date: October 8, 2015

Sometimes players and their friends aren't into the FPS or RPG scene and want to indulge in puzzles or trivia instead. Keep Talking And Nobody Explodes is similar to a virtual escape room, but in this case, the puzzle is a bomb. Players have to work together to defuse this complex explosive device, but only one of them can see it.

The other players have to put on their thinking and listening caps and follow directions. That makes teamwork, communication, and observation skills crucial to succeed. An advantage of this game is that it works on several different platforms, including Andriod, and players don't exactly need advanced software to play it.

5 Escape From Tarkov

An Unforgiving Old-School FPS

  • Developer: Battlestate Games
  • Platforms: Microsoft Windows
  • Type of Multiplayer: FPS
  • Launch Date: July 27, 2017

Escape From Tarkov is built like a classic, no-nonsense, gritty first-person shooter. It has rules that gamers from the old MMORPG world would understand, such as losing all loot and money when a character is killed.

The setting is the city of Tarkov, in a fictional region called Norvinsk that's currently hosting a war between two private armies, and the goal is to escape from the city with the most loot, weapons, or other valuables. It's already received a lot of positive attention even though a finalized version has yet to be released. Escape from Tarkov is still in development but a closed Beta has been open since 2017.

4 Dota 2

A Rewarding But Complicated RTS Game

  • Developer: Valve
  • Platforms: Windows, Linux, OS X
  • Type of Multiplayer: MOBA
  • Launch Date: July 9, 2013

Dota 2 is not exactly as hard as EVE Online or StarCraft 2 , but putting this on the list has something to do with how long it takes for one to at least become an average player. It's a strategy-based game with over 100 characters with different weaknesses, combos, play styles, and specialties, making it difficult to understand.

In addition to that, as mentioned above, Dota 2 is a teamwork game, so players need good chemistry within their group to dominate their opponents. Players can not single-handedly win the game for anyone.

3 StarCraft 2

Attention To Detail And High Micromanagement

  • Developer: Blizzard Entertainment
  • Platforms: Microsoft Windows, macOS
  • Type of Multiplayer: Real-time Strategy (RTS)
  • Launch Date: July 27, 2010

StarCraft 2 is the kind of game in which players need excellent attention to fundamental details and high micromanagement skills. Its fast-paced nature requires the players to stay on top of their game, multitask swiftly from one objective to another, and gain the map's control.

A quick summary is that StarCraft 2 is only for real gamers who have a competitive nature. Though it's one of the hardest multiplayer games and difficult to master, the outcome of trying this difficult multiplayer game will be highly rewarding.

2 Hunt: Showdown

A Lightning-Paced Survivalist FPS

  • Developer: Crytek
  • Platforms: Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4 and 5, Xbox One and Series X/S
  • Type of Multiplayer: FPS
  • Launch Date: August 27, 2019

The genre is a multiplayer first-person shooter and both the available modes have the multiplayer option. Choose "Bounty Hunt" to play through the main story of the game which consists of a few players working together to collect bounties on the bosses and use their survival skills to travel through a wild and dangerous area.

Players win Hunt: Showdown by surviving long enough to make it to the extraction point along with defeating enemies and collecting bounties The other option is the battle royale mode in the game, known as Quickplay, and just like the name implies it only has a 15-minute duration.

item.title: Zenless Zone Zero Releases Version 1.2 Update
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Zenless Zero Zone Version 1.2 was released with new characters Caesar King and Burnice White.
  • New W-Engines, story missions, and events are introduced in the update.
  • Upcoming leaks suggest the return of Nicole and new playable characters Lighter and Yanagi.

Zenless Zone Zero has released Version 1.2, with its content now available to all players. The third major Zenless Zone Zero post-launch update was unveiled in mid-September and introduces a host of exciting content including a new pair of Agents to recruit.

HoYoverse released Version 1.1 in August, marking the awaited debut of Jane Doe in Zenless Zone Zero , as well as the additions of Electric Defense Seth Lowell and Electric Stun Qingyi to the game's roster. In addition to the debut of the new characters, seven events were introduced, as well as the new story missions "Undercover R&B is a Special Episode" and "The Case of a Missing Bangboo." For players to strengthen their teams, Zenless Zone Zero brought the new W-Engines Ice-Jade Teapot, Sharpened Stinger, Peacekeeper Specialized, Gilded Blossom, and the Bangboo Rank S Officer Cui.

Zenless Zone Zero Version 1.2 has been released, with two new characters joining the game. Caesar King is a Rank S Defense Agent who leads the faction known as the Sons of Calydon and can be obtained from the Signal Search banner until October 16. Taking her place will be Burnice White, another Rank S Agent to be available on the Born to Burn banner, which is expected to run from October 16 to November 5. Like Caesar, Burnice is also a member of the Sons of Calydon, having fire as her element.

Caesar King and Burnice White Debut in Zenless Zone Zero Version 1.2

Version 1.2 added the Tusks of Fury W-Engine, Caesar's signature weapon, which increases the shields given by Defense units and the overall damage of the players' party. Another Zenless Zone Zero W-Engine to be released soon is the Flamemaker Shaker, Burnice's signature weapon. Players will be able to obtain the new Bangboo Red Moccus, the Proto Punk Drive Discs, and Chaos Jazz, explore the New Eridu Outer Ring map, and join 11 new events such as Ridu for You, Overlor's Feast, and Advanced Bounty - Routine Cleanup.

Although Version 1.2 has just arrived, leaks already point to what the HoYoverse action RPG community can expect in the coming months. One of these leaks teases the possible return of Nicole to Zenless Zone Zero , giving players a second chance to get the character. Other leaks gave details of the upcoming playable characters Lighter and Yanagi, showing that the devs are actively working to expand the game with a wide cast of captivating characters, and features to optimize the experience.

item.title: Pokemon GO Players Have Great Idea for Field Research Breakthrough Rewards
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Pokemon GO players suggest adding legendary monsters as Weekly Breakthrough Research rewards.
  • Including legendaries could motivate trainers and improve 5-star raid rotations.
  • Many fans agree with the suggestion, criticizing the current pool of weekly reward monsters.

A Pokemon GO fan has suggested improvements to the Weekly Breakthrough Research rewards by including legendary monsters. When it was released in 2016, Pokemon GO became one of the most popular mobile titles, with players still enjoying catching Pokemon while exploring the real world.

Regular players who manage to complete field research tasks for 7 consecutive days are rewarded with a Pokemon with ties to the current season. For the ongoing Max Out season in Pokemon GO , players can encounter Furfrou, Galarian Weezing, Galarian Mr. Mime, Excadrill, Jangmo-o, or Scraggy, but one player has an idea to change the Pokemon on offer to improve the overall game experience.

A Redditor going by the username Entire_Pineapple4732 suggests that Niantic should change the Weekly Breakthrough Research rewards to include legendary monsters. In a post to the r/Pokemon GO subreddit, the fan argues that having a set of legendaries, such as Articuno, Zapdos, and Moltres, as a weekly reward would not only motivate trainers to maintain research tasks but improve the 5-star raid rotations in Pokemon GO as they would free up room on Gyms for other legendaries.

Replies to the post have certainly agreed with Entire_Pineapple4732’s suggestion, noting that the pool of monsters in the Weekly Breakthrough Rewards can typically be found throughout the season, pointing to the upcoming Legendary Heroes event in Pokemon GO as an example of this. The event starts September 26 and runs until October 1 and sees Galarian Weezing, Galarian Mr. Mime, Excadrill, Jangmo-o, and Scraggy appear more frequently in the wild and raids. However, Furfrou is the exception. The Poodle Pokemon has been a mainstay of the weekly reward pool since December 2022.

Pokemon GO Weekly Breakthrough Encounters for September - December 2024

  • Available from September 3, 2024, 10:00 a.m. until December 3, 2024, 10:00 a.m local time
    • Excadrill
    • Furfrou
    • Galarian Mr. Mime
    • Galarian Weezing
    • Jangmo-o
    • Scraggy

The rewards from the Weekly Breakthrough Research aren’t the only area of the game where Niantic has come under fire. Dynamax battles are the latest addition to Pokemon GO , but players have been facing issues when trying to battle the gigantic Pokemon Beldum. Gamers report various glitches that crash the game, costing them a chance at catching the Psychic Steel-type, along with precious MP.

While fans will have to wait to see if Niantic will change up the Pokemon in the Weekly Breakthrough Rewards, there is still a lot to look forward to in the coming days. With October on the horizon, players have the Galarian Expedition event to look forward to. This event runs from October 4-11 and will see the shiny forms of the Galarian bird trio debut in Pokemon GO for the first time.

item.title: Nintendo’s Shigeru Miyamoto Comments on AI in Gaming
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Nintendo is not planning to use AI in game development, in contrast to many other studios.
  • AI is already impacting game development, with 62% of studios using it.
  • Despite concerns, Nintendo plans to stick to human developers for now.

Shigeru Miyamoto of Nintendo fame has spoken out about AI during a recent interview. With so many game developers embracing the new technology, Miyamoto has given an idea of how Nintendo feels about it and whether it will be using it going forward in projects.

Generative AI has already had an impact on numerous fields, and gaming is no different. Some developers have already announced plans to utilize AI in development, which understandably has workers in the industry anxious about their future. With so many layoffs in gaming and overall restructuring already becoming commonplace, some have worried that AI will take over some human developers' work.

As Shigeru Miyamoto himself puts it, though, Nintendo often goes in the opposite direction of its biggest competitors, and the same can be said for its position on AI. In a new interview with The New York Times (via Dexerto), Miyamoto talked a bit about AI and its place in game development with Nintendo. Miyamoto noted that Nintendo isn't planning on using AI, pointing to the company's history of standing out from the crowd. This is in keeping with what the current Nintendo president previously said about AI, noting that it wanted to "deliver value" that "cannot be created with technology alone."

The Game Industry Continues to Embrace AI

It does seem accurate to say that Nintendo is a bit of an outlier in this regard. While not every studio is using AI or even plans to, numerous developers and publishers have acknowledged that AI will or is playing a role in their upcoming titles. A Unity report alleges that 62% of game studios are already using AI, while titles like Magic: The Gathering have been criticized for their use of generative AI. EA recently showcased an AI concept that would allow users to create basic game assets within minutes while using voice commands, showing AI's potential in game development.

Generative AI is arguably just getting started, which has many gamers and developers a bit anxious about the future. For the time being, at least, it seems as though Nintendo isn't going to be one of the reasons to worry. The company has a history of its games not technically measuring up to competitors' releases purely in terms of things like polygon count and ray-tracing, yet Nintendo still delivers beautiful, captivating, and extremely fun experiences to play. While the company's stance could change someday depending on what AI is able to do as it continues to evolve, for now, Nintendo games will continue to be developed by people and not generative AI.
